title: Nigel Slater’s gazpacho with cornichon and pickle juices recipes
text:
The recipe

Finely dice, but don’t peel, 150g of courgettes, then transfer the cubes to a small bowl. Slice 8 small gherkins or cornichons lengthways and then add to the courgettes with 3 tbsp of the pickle brine from the jar. If you like, add a few pickled silverskin onions. Set aside for at least 30 minutes.

Chop 150g of cucumber, skin on, and put it into a food blender with 350g of bottled and skinned red peppers and 700g of assorted tomatoes. Process briefly, until you have a coarse textured purée.

Pour the soup into a bowl, cover and refrigerate until thoroughly chilled.

When the soup is cold, chop 3 tbsp of parsley leaves and stir in. Drain the courgettes and gherkins, reserving the juice and stir them into the gazpacho, or spoon over the top. If you like, add a little chopped chilli. Spoon the pickle juice from the courgette over the soup and serve. Enough for 2.

The trick

This soup is something to eat with bread and cheese for a light summer meal. To be at its best the soup should be served thoroughly chilled, by which I mean it will need a good hour or so in the fridge. You can help to chill it quickly by adding a little ice to the blender, though not so much that you dilute its fiery summer flavours. If you have a coarse mouli grater then use that in place of a blender. The texture will be nigh-on perfect.

The twist

You can use the soup as a sauce. Throw some shelled prawns into a shallow pan of sizzling butter, let them pop and splutter and take the short journey from grey to pink, then ladle in the gazpacho and its pickle juices. Alternatively, continue to use it as soup, but add some heat by introducing a few chopped green guindilla chillies – the sort that curl up at the end like a sultan’s slippers.

Follow Nigel on Twitter @NigelSlater
description: A vinegary spin on a chilled summer classic. By Nigel Slater
